title: -idinu
defList: (archaic) -en (indicates item is made from a substance, cf. la. <cite>-eus</cite>)
notes: has the alternate form -dinu after a vowel

title: -idzu
defList: -en (indicates item is made from a substance, cf. la. <cite>-eus</cite>)
notes: has the alternate form -dzu after a vowel

title: -isu
notes: has the alternate form -su after a vowel

title: -r
notes: In PZ dialects, -r and -rre remain unmerged.

title: -u
defList: (archaic) verbal suffix used to form relative clauses

title: -ulk
notes: has the alternate form -lk after a vowel

title: -z
defList: turns a time noun (eg. dam morning) into a habitual time adverb (eg. daz every morning)
turns a direction adjective into an adverb, (eg. keu 'east' → kez 'eastward'

title: abelk
notes: Often used in places where English would use 'would've'.

title: abu
notes: abu is one of a handful of nouns ending in -u.

title: ad
defList: (prep.) to, towards (in both the dative and lative senses)
(post., inanimate only) have: X Y ad = Y has X
(adverb) about to, going to, (forms near future aspect)

title: afêkz
notes: Unlike English, this is not used with subordinate clauses, including reporting knowledge of experiences - evidentials are used for that instead. In addition, bakaz is telic and dynamic, while afêkz is atelic and stative.

title: akaban
defList: Akaban (the bay at the mouth of the Akkapa)

title: akku
notes: See bo for the standard instrumental

title: aramaelat
defList: (obsolete) small copper piece, worth a quarter aramat

title: aramat
defList: copper piece, worth one quarter of a nelat

title: ardo
notes: further etymology of *xere: *x [animacy particle] + *ere 'red'

title: arrôr
notes: PEN is a nominalization of *xêrrôs from *xêd 'to' + *rôs 'speak'; Related to Numoran Xerror

title: arzênelat
defList: small silver piece, worth four aramat

title: astedu
notes: Cf. uzurkelau.

title: azaz
notes: azmu is one of a handful of nouns ending in -u.

title: azmu
notes: azmu is one of a handful of nouns ending in -u.

title: badmak
defList: fox (esp. vulpes vulpes, vulpes cana, & vulpes ruepellii)

title: bakaz
notes: Unlike English, this is not used with subordinate clauses, including reporting knowledge of experiences - evidentials are used for that instead. cf. bakaz, a similar meaning with opposite transitivity. In addition, bakaz is telic and dynamic, while afêkz is atelic and stative.

title: balis
notes: Note: With causative, means kill.

title: baliz
notes: X trades Y for Z's A - X dir Y ad A Z ad baliz

title: ban
defList: (negative) hardly, barely, not at all, not even

title: barsum
defList: Don, the fifth planet from Namei

title: bat
notes: n., 3rd

title: baztur
defList: Važcud (the people and country, but not the language)
notes: A popular folk etymology derives this word from bazêr 'leader' + tum 'sky' - 'sky leader' - and this belief is reinforced by the ancient claim that the royalty descends from planet Don, where they were exiled after a power struggle. This leads to occasional hypercorrection to *Bazêtur.

title: be
notes: see id and nanau for ors linking nominals

title: bikêm
defList: two decades (in Earth years: 4 yr 1 mo 7 d)

title: bilu
notes: bilu is one of a handful of nouns ending in -u.

title: bo
notes: see ku for the comitative

title: bokusam
defList:
much, many, a large quantity
  • morMOR iI bokusamBOKUSAM
  • There are many people.
notes: cf. udou, the adjective form, and pukusam, the opposite form

title: bonrôm
defList: bonrôm, a traditional artform characterized by rhythmic performance of poetry (cf. spoken word, rap)

title: breka
notes: Synonym: dirabeka

title: bubuk
notes: irregular; expected form would be *pipidzak, but pidzak is a loanword

title: busk
defList: owned dog (specifically, one that is not feral or stray)
notes: Feral/stray dogs are called lusik 'wolf'

title: da
notes: This does not translate country or nation in all English uses. When referring to an ethnos, use mor instead.

title: dalu
defList: (of the sky) having moderate cloud cover

title: dammam
defList: ereyesterday, the day before yesterday, two days ago

title: danealm
etym: L/POL/Dnejal/Named after Dnejal, a royal courtier of the early Temêsur dynasty infamous for his haughty and often clueless remarks.

title: dantam
defList: overmorrow, the day after tomorrow, two days hence

title: darekut
defList: large gold coin, worth four daret

title: daz
notes: be tired of X: X kul daz

title: defôz
defList: [particle assuring the listener of what has been said]

title: di
notes: Nowadays replaced by ou. Reanalyzed as a preposition in most dialects, including the standard.

title: din
defList: ~ give/take*: X i Y ad Z din = Z gives X to Y
(informal, ardo i +) ~ (romantic) love*: Y ad Z din = Y loves Z
(prefix) dis-, un- (verbal prefix showing undoing/removal of a state)
notes: Note: * - There are many possible arrangements of this phrase. To emphasize the recipient, ad may even be replaced by dir. The most neutral phrasing is shown. ZE dialects use this prepositionally for translative senses.

title: dinkalz
defList: ask for guidance, help, aid, etc

title: dinrôz
notes: In the sense of "mean", what is the direct object in English would be construed with lative ad "to".

title: dirabeka
notes: Synonym: breka

title: dirak
defList: dolphin (esp. delphinus delphis, lagendodelphis hosei, platanista, sousa plumbea, stenella, and tursiops)

title: dô
defList: on (ie. 'on a wall' but not 'on a table')
notes: ZE dialects use this prepositionally for translative senses.

title: dôkaz
notes: Replaced the now-obsolete kunz.

title: dômo
notes: Always sentence-initial

title: dou
notes: cf. pukusam, the noun form

title: drekut
defList: large gold coin, worth four daret

title: edzam
defList: unit of measurement equal to one-quarter of one labnim (~42.6 mm)

title: empra
notes: wanderwort

title: erem
notes: Note: used with tar (tar seerem) and muk (muk seerem) for dawn and dusk, respectively.

title: habiz
defList: live (vivere, non habitare, quid est ~ dô momtantan)

title: hai
notes: Can ONLY modify adjectives/adverbs, not verbs.

title: hal
defList: (prefix) (verbal prefix denoting the “natural consequence” of an action)

title: hans
defList:
and*
  • Rurauk su lusik su dir hans i uzurkuk.
    cat GEN dog GEN ABS all TOP good
    I like both cats and dogs.
notes: Due to historical reasons, this word has an irregular spelling; *hanz would be expected. There also exist the rare conjunctions unau 'nor', ufans 'nand', and unanau 'xnor', generally only used in formal writing

title: hanum
defList:
(noun + su +) [used to indicate an outcome effected with the hands]; by hand, ahold
  • Sazam i afêst su dir hanum zestisudôz ômôrz.
    awe TOP shortsword GEN ABS hold bent-CAUS EXP.PL
    We were amazed to see him bend the shortsword by hand.

title: hekz
notes: See zurkrôz

title: ho
defList: that, those (away from speaker and listener)

title: hunik
defList: hunik (large yellow mammal related to the echidna)

title: i
notes: Used to make have/give constructions like ad when the possessor is animate

title: id
defList:
or (exclusive)*
  • Rurauk su lusik su dir id i uzurkuk.
    cat GEN dog GEN ABS or TOP good
    I like either cats or dogs.

(ko +) the same individual, the thing just mentioned: (cf. "se" in Latin, proximate pronoun)
  • Mor i lulz ku, kor id i libaz.
    person TOP laugh and, "the same person" TOP cry
    The person laughed, and then they [same person] cried.

(hoki/ho +) the other individual, the other thing recently mentioned: (cf. obviative pronoun)
  • Mor i lulz ku, hor id i libaz.
    person TOP laugh and, "the other person" TOP cry
    The person laughed, and then they [another person] cried.
(+ plural det) considering each member of the determiner equally, eg. id hans = "every" specifically rather than all. (Distributive pronoun/determiner)
notes: See be for an or linking clauses. cf. nanau, inclusive or and "quelque" some. The choice of hoki vs. ho with the obviative mostly has to do with whether the person is close in relation or proximity to the listener

title: irerz
notes: used of the final product, NOT ingredients - cf. en. brew - used esp. of tea

title: irikar
defList: the Irikar (a people in the near part of the western mountains who are stereotyped to be hoaxsters)

title: kaldoz
notes: Unlike English, this verb is not catenative, and only takes nouns as direct objects. To express wanna, one would use the optative.

title: kamit
defList: any drink brewed with hot water except tea (from Camellia sinensis), including herbal teas and coffee

title: kaskru
notes: kaskru is one of a handful of nouns ending in -u.

title: kasu
notes: kasu is one of a handful of nouns ending in -u.

title: ke
notes: Always comes directly after the word modified.

title: ki
defList: (+ ad) standing still, standing stiff, in place

title: kikbil
defList: city on the foothills of the Nadnekis, or the small nation it controls.

title: klu
notes: klu is one of a handful of nouns ending in -u.

title: kôbensu
notes: cf. en. mousy and la. murinus, mirroring senses 3-5.

title: kokum
defList: The third of three seasons of the Eremoran calendar

title: kopam
notes: See usage notes for kopz

title: kopz
notes: Only for familial/romantic/friendly relations. Not used in the sense of 'I like this music' - you would use X i ad Y uzurku or similar.

title: kotaz
notes: Note: this verb forms many compounds. (TODO; Will add soon!)

title: krarnok
defList: pig (esp. sus scrofa and porcula salvania)

title: ku
notes: See bo for the instrumental. See hans for an and linking nominals.

title: kubatu
notes: see batu for the verbal "too"

title: kudôz
notes: <sup>1</sup> Habitual aspect only

title: kunaba
defList: root vegetable (esp. radishes, but also carrots and parsnips)

title: laku
notes: Displaced by synonym uzurku after laku became sarcastic

title: len
notes: Apparently dissimilated from lel

title: lennama
defList: prunus (subgenus; incl. plums, peaches, nectarines, apricots, and almonds)

title: libada
defList: Libada, the central hilly cultural region of Eremor, often portrayed as rustic and uncultured.

title: lôtor
notes: Related to Numoran Flotwer and Lotwer

title: lusik
notes: Owned dogs are called busk

title: marama
defList: iron ore (esp. hematite, limonite, and magnetite)

title: mekrak
defList: mekrak (a parastitic flatworm used primarily in torture and occasionally medicinally for its behavior-altering effects)

title: melat
defList: (obsolete) small copper piece, worth a quarter aramat

title: mi
defList: [a component in various explicitly ad hoc first or second person pronouns, like rô-mi]

title: mid
defList: in one's possession, on one's person

title: minibak
notes: Note: despite being animate, this refers to unfertilized eggs, too.

title: mok
notes: Roughly equivalent to 'is/has at/since some time previous...'; cf. la. iam

title: mor
notes: This does not translate country or nation in all English uses. When referring to territory, use da instead.

title: morôz
defList: [Specifies the speaker heard of the event mentioned]

title: mu
notes: mu is one of a handful of nouns ending in -u.

title: mukink
defList: otter (sp. lutra lutra, lutrogale perspicillata, and to a lesser extent aonyx cinereus)

title: musu
notes: not humid

title: na
notes: Modern Eremoran uses nau, which was originally just the determiner form.

title: nadnekis
defList: Nadnekis, the great east mountain range.

title: nakanar
defList: Nekang (the people and country, but not the language)

title: nanau
defList:
or (inclusive)*
  • Rurauk su lusik su dir nanauk i uzurkuk.
    cat GEN dog GEN ABS or TOP good
    I like either cats or dogs.
notes: See be for the verbal conjunction. cf. id.

title: nask
notes: Note: this word does not refer to carnivores in general, only carnivorans.

title: nasu
defList: (+ plural det) considering each member of the determiner in pairs, eg. nasu hans = "every pair" specifically rather than all. (Distributive pronoun/determiner)
notes: While possible with greater numerals, it is rather rare.

title: nasum abbakarm
defList: The north plains, a cultural region of Eremor, often portrayed as excessively warlike (even by Eremoran standards); outsiders belive everyone from the region is a soldier-turned-farmer - and they are largely correct. In terms of speech, they are mocked as 'always breathy', as they are one of the few regions to retain /h/, but also merge /r/ into /h/.

title: nelat
defList: small silver piece, worth four aramat

title: nem
notes: not used for giving the ages of people; skum is used instead

title: nes
defList: bedroom (but more broadly, one's typical place of sleep)
notes: Typically refers to where the speaker usually sleeps, often a bedroom.

title: nizitnôr
defList: Pre-Eremoran (the people and country, but not the language)

title: nub
notes: Due to historical reasons, this word has an irregular spelling; *nu would be expected.

title: nuzderar
defList: Nuzderar (the people and country, but not the language)

title: ô
defList: Anyways..., so... (used similarly to jp. ja, fr. alors)

title: oddomsumor
defList: Oddomsumor, a conquered tribe (sumor) in the mid-east of Eremor.

title: ok
notes: Eye-dialect spelling of holk in L-dropping dialects. The k is occasionally pronounced as a glottal stop.

title: ôkar
defList: wife (in monogamous relationships; esp. someone else's)

title: omor
notes: see Pronouns for more details

title: omôr
notes: see Pronouns for more details

title: omôrz
defList: [Specifies the speaker, and others, saw the event mentioned]
notes: cf. umôrz which implies the speaker was the sole witness

title: onodlusik
defList: deer (esp. axis porcinus, cervus hanglu hanglu, rucervus duvaucelii, and to a lesser extent muntiacus muntjak, axis axis, and rusa unicolor)
musk deer (esp. moschus cupreus and moschus leucogaster)
gazelle (esp. gazella bennettii, and to a lesser extent gazella subgutturosa)

title: ou
defList: [affix used to form first/second person personal pronouns, eg. môk]
notes: Irregular spelling; 'hou' would be expected, but apparently the lower-register pronounciation became dominant

title: pankair
defList: Pankair, the continent on which lies Eremor.

title: pi
defList: onomatopoeia for something sparkly or shiny

title: pipibubu
notes: (specifically, a compound of their reduplications - *pibu is unattested)

title: pu-
notes: cf. u-, the older, non-productive form

title: pukusam
defList:
a small quantity, few
  • morMOR iI pukusamPUKUSAM
  • There are few people.
notes: cf. dou, the adjective form, and bokusam, the opposite form

title: raratit
defList: meat (in general, including flesh and fish)

title: razbakum
notes: esp. of interior wall painting patterns; present form influenced by raz 'paint'

title: rênaz
notes: Can be used with the causative to mean 'pickle'. Can be used as an adjective to mean 'pickled'.

title: reram
defList: The second of three seasons of the Eremoran calendar

title: rôraz
defList: (+dir tikat ad X) hone X (a skill or weapon)

title: rôz
notes: Unlike English, the direct object is the person being spoken to/with, and the content being spoken is construed with bo "with; using".

title: ruskank
defList: zothceng (a large, semi-intelligent symbiotic fungus-beehive beast)

title: sarm
defList: unit of area equivalent to 50 square labnim, or about 1.452 m<sup>2</sup>

title: sart
defList: mat, typically in the dimensions of 5-by-10 labnim

title: saurom
notes: irregular spelling; 'sauram' would be expected, but it was likely influenced by suro 'eye'

title: sazaz
notes: Note: with causative, means "scare".

title: se
defList: unit of measurement equal to one-fifteenth of one edzam (~2.84 mm)

title: sedam
defList: unit of area about 3,100 m^2 or 0.76 acres

title: ses
defList:
substellar object orbiting a star
  1. (by extension) planet
  2. (by extension) minor planet
  3. (by extension) comet

title: set
defList: crop (ie. plant used to produce goods)

title: sirez
notes: a rather old blend; it retains ar(e)do's central vowel

title: sisikruêr
notes: In Eremoran times, these two roles are functioned by the same person

title: sisikrum
notes: In Eremoran times, these two roles are functioned by the same person

title: siu
defList: (of the sky) overcast, but not with stormclouds (which would be usiu; cf. perlucidus and translucidus)

title: skôkiz
notes: With the causative suffix, means 'hurl' or 'send'.

title: sou
defList: right (ie. the opposite of left, rather than the opposite of wrong)
androphilic (ie. gay male or heterosexual female)

title: stanu
notes: stanu is one of a handful of nouns ending in -u.

title: stôd
notes: Full derivation: su tô ad

title: stum
defList: The first of three seasons of the Eremoran calendar

title: su
defList: of, belonging to or made of

title: subanbanz
notes: note: implies other people were present who also experienced something

title: sudôz
defList: (animate subject and object) fuck; have sex with
(animate subject, inanimate object, of a consumable1) enjoy
(inanimate subject, human object) be a cause of termination for
notes: <sup>1</sup> Habitual aspect only; supplanted the now-archaic dôz in most senses

title: tasku
notes: tasku is one of a handful of nouns ending in -u.

title: taze dô kadôl
defList: someone or something that stands out among the crowd in some positive aspect, especially beauty

title: tekkat
notes: The color adjectives kanut (yellow), siut (white), and tasut (green) can be applied to tekkat with an identical meaning to English. However, ulut (blue/black) is used to refer to oolong, and eret (red) is used to refer to black tea, likely in reference to the color of the leaves. It is also important to note that usiut (black/dark) cannot be used interchangably with ulut; the former refers instead to fermented tea instead of oolong.

title: tôda
defList: The southern, coastal cultural region of Eremor, associated with the so-called kadrêm 'hard R' sounds.

title: tranzu
notes: Irregular. Expected form *tranu unattested.

title: tum
defList: set of objects visible overhead from a reference point

title: u-
notes: cf. pu-, the newer, productive form

title: udou
defList:
(with id) (the) most (incl. superlative)
  • Rurauk i id -udou kopdoz.
    cat TOP most like
    I like cats the most.
notes: cf. bokusam, the noun form

title: ufomor
notes: see Pronouns for more details

title: ufomôrz
defList: [Specifies the speaker, but not others, saw the event mentioned]
notes: cf. omôrz which implies others witnessed the event too

title: ufou
defList: [affix used to form first/second person personal pronouns]

title: ulu
notes: For black specifically, see usiu

title: ur
defList: therefore, thus, so, for this/that reason

title: usiu
defList: (of the sky) overcast with storm clouds; having heavy cloud cover

title: utbak
defList: bear (sp. ursus thibetanus, and to a lesser extent ursus arctos and melursus ursinus)

title: utôzmu
defList: darn, dang, oh well, how unfortunate

title: zikrômbor
defList: Goddess of Manners and Disease, she curses those who do not practice good manners with various afflictions. It is never used as a given name. It is used in the interj. Zikrômbor berbkaldoz (gesundheit; bless you; literally "May Zikrômbor leave you.").
notes: possibly related to zurku

title: zurkrôz
notes: See hekz
